info.game_comments:
2008 College Championship semifinal game 3.
From the Kohl Center at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

double_jeopardy_round: THE NEW YORK TIMES TECH BIZ

(1, 1).clue: Desdemona's lady-in-waiting is Emilia, this man's wife

(2, 1).clue: Dad refuses to see a Guy Ritchie film because he's always had a secret crush on this "Like A Virgin" singer

(3, 1).clue: Ice cream bars shaped like this celebrity cetacean are a special treat at Sea World

(4, 1).clue: This "great" Russian czar tricked his wayward son Alexis into coming home--bad move for Alex

(6, 1).clue: A typical coffee berry contains 2 of these that are roasted, ground & brewed to make coffee

(1, 2).clue: Much of Act V of this play is set at Dunsinane Castle

(2, 2).clue: Dad slow dances by himself to this band's "Stairway to Heaven" becuase he's having school dance flashbacks

(3, 2).clue: You could say that this theme park in Billund, Denmark was built block by (plastic) block

(4, 2).clue: Playwright who introduced us to a title uncle & later to "Three Sisters"

(5, 2).clue: An outrage to one's sensibilities or half the players on a football field

(6, 2).clue: Get your butt in gear & know this anatomical term for a small zippered pouch suspended from a belt

(1, 3).clue: A shipwreck separates twin siblings Viola & Sebastian in this comedy

(2, 3).clue: Dad wears that dorky clock on a chain because he was into this Public Enemy before he became a VH1 reality star

(3, 3).clue: A highlight of Silver Dollar City in Branson is a tour of Marvel Cave, the deepest cave in this state

(4, 3).clue: The only son of Nicholas II, Alexis was the last male heir born to this royal family while it ruled Russia

(6, 3).clue: Heart attack survivor Kerry Packer gave $3 mil. for portable these, aka "Packer Whackers", to local ambulances

(1, 4).clue: Most of "Hamlet" is set in this Danish seaport

(2, 4).clue: Dad thinks he's an O.G. because he was into these white rappers long before their album "Ill Communication"

(3, 4).clue: Uh-oh! Monsieur Cannibale wants you to ride in a cooking pot at Efteling theme park in this low country

(4, 4).clue: On April 14, 1961 this cosmonaut was awarded the honor "Hero of the Soviet Union"

(5, 4).clue: A colonel or a major, but not a sergeant

(6, 4).clue: On June 28, 1919 the buck stopped for Bess Wallace when she married this young man, home from WWI

(1, 5).clue: He's described as "The triple pillar of the world transformed into a strumpet's fool"

(2, 5).clue: Dad needs help downloading "In Rainbows", but he always said this Thom Yorke band was ahead of its time

(3, 5).clue: Can-can girls have returned to N.C.: Ghost Town in the Sky has re-opened in these "Great" mountains

(4, 5).clue: This chemist developed the periodic table, & element 101 was later named for him

(5, 5).clue: An unaccented unit in music, or an adjective meaning "unusual"

(6, 5).clue: In 1861 a brewer with this last name gave $408,000 to the trustees at a Poughkeepsie women's college

(1, 1).clue: The name of this state capital & port city is French for "red stick"

(2, 1).clue: This conservative radio talk show host dropped out of SE Missouri State after flunking ballroom dancing

(3, 1).clue: The Turkish Angora is named for this Turkish city

(4, 1).clue: The Times exposed memos from this company's execs who had trouble upgrading to its Vista operating system

(5, 1).clue: Desmond Llewelyn played this gadget man in 17 James Bond films

(6, 1).clue: On March 4, 2008 this Packer quarterback called it quits (probably)

(1, 2).clue: One of the world's largest steel plants can be found in this Indiana city named for a chairman of U.S. Steel

(2, 2).clue: This Russian novelist dropped out of college after 3 years & then wrote "Anna Karenina"

(3, 2).clue: The "fold" in the name of the Scottish Fold refers to these folded-down features

(4, 2).clue: Hoping to regain its luster, this Time Warner online service is buying the no. 3 social networking site, Bebo

(5, 2).clue: In the English alphabet, it's the only polysyllabic letter

(6, 2).clue: He hit 22 of his 755 career HRs as a Brewer; he hit 398 as a Milwaukee Brave

(1, 3).clue: Bartholomew Gosnold may have named this Mass. island for his daughter & for the plants he found there

(2, 3).clue: She dropped out of Columbia Univ. to sign with Columbia Records & later won a Grammy for "My Boo"

(3, 3).clue: This color follows "Russian" in the name of a cat breed; it actually refers to various shades of gray

(4, 3).clue: The Times cites an estimate that in 2007, its 3rd year, this site used as much bandwidth as the entire Internet in 2000

(5, 3).clue: Used with an apostrophe, this letter can be a contraction of had, would & did

(6, 3).clue: In 1970-71 this master of the skyhook averaged 31.7 ppg & led the Bucks to an NBA title

(1, 4).clue: Haakon County, South Dakota was named for a king of this country

(2, 4).clue: After dropping out of the Univ. of Maryland, he exposed the Watergate scandal with Bob Woodward

(3, 4).clue: Eugene Field's poem "The Duel" tells of a fight between a gingham dog & this cat, a tortoiseshell & white coat pattern

(4, 4).clue: The Times reported Best Buy is giving $50 gift cards to buyers of this format that is on the losing end of the video battle

(5, 4).clue: On a bowling scoresheet, a diagonal line represents a spare & this letter, a strike

(6, 4).clue: Guess winning was the only thing for him; he coached the Pack to 5 NFL titles

(1, 5).clue: He wrote the poem from which Pippa Passes, Kentucky took its name

(2, 5).clue: This inspirational TV pastor dropped out of Oral Roberts University before writing the bestseller "Your Best Life Now"

(3, 5).clue: The riddle of this cat breed seen here: Is it a pet, or is it art?

(4, 5).clue: The David Pogue blog says the iPhone with push email is gunning for this most popular smartphone

(5, 5).clue: All Japanese words end in a vowel or this consonant

(6, 5).clue: "Royal" first name of Mr. Fielder, who hit 50 HRs for the Brewers in 2007; his first name is this, & he is funky"

(0, 0).clue: In the last week of the John Tyler administration, this republic was offered statehood
